node.title: Omicron Is Milder
node.alt: Treating covid patients at a hospital in Worcester, Mass., yesterday.
node.description: How should that affect your behavior?
node.content: ["The details of the Omicron variant are becoming clearer, and they are encouraging.", "They\u2019re not entirely encouraging, and I will get into some detail about one of the biggest problems \u2014 the stress on hospitals, which are facing huge numbers of moderately ill Covid-19 patients. But regular readers of this newsletter know that I try to avoid the bad-news bias that often infects journalism. (We journalists tend to be comfortable delivering bad news straight up but uncomfortable reporting good news without extensive caveats.)", "So I want to be clear: The latest evidence about Covid is largely positive. A few weeks ago, many experts and journalists were warning that the initial evidence from South Africa \u2014 suggesting that Omicron was milder than other variants \u2014 might turn out to be a mirage. It has turned out to be real.", "\u201cIn hospitals around the country, doctors are taking notice,\u201d my colleagues Emily Anthes and Azeen Ghorayshi write. \u201cThis wave of Covid seems different from the last one.\u201d", "There are at least three main ways that Omicron looks substantially milder than other versions of the virus:", "Somebody infected with Omicron is less likely to need hospital treatment than somebody infected with an earlier version of Covid.", "An analysis of patients in Houston, for example, found that Omicron patients were only about one-third as likely to need hospitalization as Delta patients. In Britain, people with Omicron were about half as likely to require hospital care, the government reported. The pattern looks similar in Canada, Emily and Azeen note.", "Hospitalizations are nonetheless rising in the U.S., because Omicron is so contagious that it has led to an explosion of cases. Many hospitals are running short of beds and staff, partly because of Covid-related absences. In Maryland, more people are hospitalized with Covid than ever.", "\u201cThankfully the Covid patients aren\u2019t as sick. But there\u2019s so many of them,\u201d Craig Spencer, an emergency room doctor in New York, tweeted on Monday, after a long shift. \u201cThe next few weeks will be really, really tough for us.\u201d", "The biggest potential problem is that overwhelmed hospitals will not be able to provide patients \u2014 whether they have Covid or other conditions \u2014 with straightforward but needed care. Some may die as a result. That possibility explains why many epidemiologists still urge people to take measures to reduce Covid\u2019s spread during the Omicron surge. It\u2019s likely to last at least a couple more weeks in the U.S.", "Omicron is not just less likely to send somebody to the hospital. Even among people who need hospital care, symptoms are milder on average than among people who were hospitalized in previous waves.", "A crucial reason appears to be that Omicron does not attack the lungs as earlier versions of Covid did. Omicron instead tends to be focused in the nose and throat, causing fewer patients to have breathing problems or need a ventilator.", "As Dr. Rahul Sharma of NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell told The Times, \u201cWe\u2019re not sending as many patients to the I.C.U., we\u2019re not intubating as many patients, and actually, most of our patients that are coming to the emergency department that do test positive are actually being discharged.\u201d", "In London, the number of patients on ventilators has remained roughly constant in recent weeks, even as the number of cases has soared, John Burn-Murdoch of The Financial Times noted.", "In the U.S., mortality trends typically trail case trends by about three weeks \u2014 which means the Omicron surge, which began more than a month ago, should be visible in the death counts. It isn\u2019t yet:", "Covid deaths will still probably rise in the U.S. in coming days or weeks, many experts say. For one thing, data can be delayed around major holidays. For another, millions of adults remain unvaccinated and vulnerable.", "But the increase in deaths is unlikely to be anywhere near as large as the increase last summer, during the Delta wave. Look at the data from South Africa, where the Omicron wave is already receding:", "Given the combination of surging cases and milder disease, how should people respond?", "Dr. Leana Wen, Baltimore\u2019s former health commissioner, wrote a helpful Washington Post article in which she urged a middle path between reinstituting lockdowns and allowing Omicron to spread unchecked.", "\u201cIt\u2019s unreasonable to ask vaccinated people to refrain from pre-pandemic activities,\u201d Wen said. \u201cAfter all, the individual risk to them is low, and there is a steep price to keeping students out of school, shuttering restaurants and retail shops and stopping travel and commerce.\u201d", "But she urged people to get booster shots, recommended that they wear KN95 or N95 masks and encouraged governments and businesses to mandate vaccination. All of those measures can reduce the spread of Covid and, by extension, hospital crowding and death.", "What about elderly or immunocompromised people, who have been at some risk of major Covid illness even if they\u2019re vaccinated?", "Different people will make different decisions, and that\u2019s OK. Severely immunocompromised people \u2014 like those who have received organ transplants or are actively receiving cancer treatment \u2014 have reason to be extra cautious. For otherwise healthy older people, on the other hand, the latest data may be encouraging enough to affect their behavior.", "Consider this: Before Omicron, a typical vaccinated 75-year-old who contracted Covid had a roughly similar risk of death \u2014 around 1 in 200 \u2014 as a typical 75-year-old who contracted the flu. (Here are the details behind that calculation, which is based on an academic study.)", "Omicron has changed the calculation. Because it is milder than earlier versions of the virus, Covid now appears to present less threat to most vaccinated elderly people than the annual flu does.", "The flu, of course, does present risk for the elderly. And the sheer size of the Omicron surge may argue for caution over the next few weeks. But the combination of vaccines and Omicron\u2019s apparent mildness means that, for an individual, Covid increasingly resembles the kind of health risk that people accept every day.", "More on the virus:", "Relaxing is a skill. Farhad Manjoo has tips.", "Two years into the pandemic, public health officials still aren\u2019t leveling with us, Zeynep Tufekci writes.", "Taste: Tejal Rao explains how Los Angeles developed America\u2019s most robust sushi scene.", "Ask Well: Can you exercise too much?", "Faking it: The epic rise and fall of Elizabeth Holmes.", "The 30,000-acre lab: Wildfire research is helping foresters prepare for a hotter planet.", "Live long and prosper: An exhibit explores the Jewish roots of \u201cStar Trek.\u201d", "Lives Lived: Lisa Brodyaga took on the cases of refugees fleeing bloodshed in Central America pro bono and was a thorn in the side of border agencies. She died at 81.", "In 1996, \u201cScream\u201d turned every slasher trope on its head: Its characters were talky and well-versed in the genre\u2019s rules, rolling their eyes at its clich\u00e9s. The movie infused horror with self-aware humor, inspiring many imitators and reviving its director Wes Craven\u2019s career. His final film before his death would be \u201cScream 4\u201d in 2011.", "After more than a decade, Neve Campbell, Courteney Cox and David Arquette have returned to the meta-horror franchise with a new film. The plot: another killer in a Ghostface mask is plaguing the fictional town of Woodsboro, demanding the attention of the original trio.", "The shoot was moving for Arquette. In circumstances mirroring the former couple\u2019s real life, Arquette and Cox acted out a story in which their \u201cScream\u201d characters have split up. \u201cThere were moments when I felt Wes\u2019s spirit around a lot,\u201d he said. \u201cThere would be a wind blowing and I\u2019d see Courteney\u2019s hair move back. And then it\u2019s just like \u2014\u201d He made an exaggeratedly mournful weeping noise. \u201cIt made it really easy to tap into those feelings.\u201d", "Campbell said she was grateful to play a horror-movie heroine who wasn\u2019t a helpless victim. \u201cI\u2019m very lucky, as a woman, to have gotten a role where people come up to me and say, \u2018Sidney Prescott inspired me \u2014 Sidney Prescott made me more courageous, made me less insecure, made me stand up for myself,\u2019\u201d she said. \u2014 Sanam Yar, a Morning writer", "Sheet-pan recipe of the week: Roasted butternut squash bread salad, an earthy take on panzanella.", "Jean Chen Ho\u2019s debut story collection, \u201cFiona and Jane,\u201d follows the milestones of growing up, Tammy Tarng writes in a review.", "5 minutes that will make you love the mezzo-soprano voice.", "Stephen Colbert has a backup plan for parents in the pandemic.", "The pangram from yesterday\u2019s Spelling Bee was pantheon.
